content: I've noticed that most APIs for AI consists of a JSON Rest API. How might soap be useful, in these cases? What does it offer that's difficult to do in JSON? Study the Open AI, Anthropic, and Hugging Face APIs. Thanks you in advance!
Great question ‚Äî you're right that OpenAI, Anthropic, and Hugging Face all use JSON-based REST APIs (sometimes with WebSocket/streaming extensions). SOAP feels almost

next to that, but there are reasons it still exists, and thinking about it in the AI API context helps illustrate the differences.

Why JSON REST APIs Dominate Today

Simplicity & Familiarity: JSON over HTTP is lightweight, human-readable, and easy to consume in almost any language with built-in libraries. Developers don't need heavy toolchains.

Flexibility: REST APIs can evolve quickly ‚Äî new fields can be added without breaking existing clients.

Ecosystem Fit: OpenAI, Anthropic, and Hugging Face focus on fast iteration, cloud-native deployments, and developer accessibility, all of which pair better with REST/JSON.

What SOAP Offers That JSON REST Doesn't (or Makes Hard)

SOAP isn't just a serialization format ‚Äî it's a full protocol with built-in features:

Strong Typing & Contracts

SOAP uses WSDL (Web Services Description Language) to strictly define service operations, inputs, and outputs.

In theory, this enforces better guarantees than a JSON schema. A bank or enterprise IT system can auto-generate type-safe client code directly from WSDL.

For AI: this could ensure you always send the right structure to a model API, preventing

issues.

Transport Neutrality

SOAP is not tied to HTTP; it can run over SMTP, JMS, raw TCP, etc.

JSON REST is almost always HTTP-centric.

For AI: if you wanted model calls over message queues (e.g., for batch training jobs inside a corporate ESB), SOAP could be a natural fit.

Built-in Error Handling

SOAP has a formal Fault structure that describes errors in a standardized way.

JSON APIs vary a lot (e.g., OpenAI uses {error: {...}}, Anthropic has its own shape). SOAP clients know exactly how to catch and parse faults.

Security Standards (WS-Security, WS-ReliableMessaging, WS-AtomicTransaction)

SOAP comes with a large ecosystem of specs for:

Signing and encrypting messages at the field level

Ensuring guaranteed delivery

Coordinating multi-party transactions

For AI: useful if model calls need to be auditable, tamper-proof, or coordinated across systems (e.g., healthcare, defense, regulated finance).

Extensibility via Headers

SOAP envelopes have standardized headers for metadata (auth, routing, transactions).

JSON APIs reinvent this ‚Äî e.g., OpenAI puts metadata in HTTP headers or JSON fields. SOAP provides a single, interoperable place.

Why SOAP Hasn't Been Adopted in AI APIs

Looking at OpenAI, Anthropic, and Hugging Face:

Their users are developers, researchers, and startups who value speed and ease over strict enterprise contracts.

SOAP's verbosity (XML envelopes, WSDL, WS-* extensions) would be a huge barrier compared to curl https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions -d '{...}'.

The AI ecosystem evolves too fast ‚Äî SOAP's rigidity is a mismatch with APIs that frequently add new models, parameters, or experimental features.

Where SOAP Could Be Useful in AI APIs

Enterprise/regulated integrations: AI services inside banks, hospitals, or government might expose SOAP to plug into existing middleware that already requires WS-Security or WSDL contracts.

Guaranteed delivery pipelines: e.g., an AI moderation API inside a messaging backbone that must confirm every request was processed exactly once.

Strong contract enforcement: SOAP could reduce

issues by making schema mismatch impossible at compile-time for generated clients.

‚úÖ Summary:
SOAP brings formal contracts, security, reliability, and enterprise integration ‚Äî features that JSON REST usually rebuilds in ad hoc ways. But OpenAI, Anthropic, and Hugging Face optimize for developer accessibility and speed, so JSON REST is the natural fit for their audiences. If AI services become deeply embedded in regulated enterprise workflows, SOAP might see niche adoption there.

Would you like me to sketch a hypothetical SOAP WSDL contract for something like CreateChatCompletion (OpenAI's most used endpoint), so you can see how it contrasts with the JSON REST version?
Yes, please. I would love to see that comparison.

Perfect ‚Äî let's contrast OpenAI's chat.completions REST JSON API with how the same thing might look if it were defined in SOAP/WSDL.

1. REST/JSON (current reality)
http
Copy code
POST https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions
Authorization: Bearer <api_key>
Content-Type: application/json

json
Copy code
{
  "model": "gpt-4.1",
  "messages": [
    {"role": "system", "content": "You are a helpful assistant."},
    {"role": "user", "content": "Write me a poem about SOAP vs JSON."}
  ],
  "temperature": 0.7,
  "stream": false
}


Response:

json
Copy code
{
  "id": "chatcmpl-123",
  "object": "chat.completion",
  "created": 1723456789,
  "model": "gpt-4.1",
  "choices": [
    {
      "index": 0,
      "message": {"role": "assistant", "content": "Here's a poem..."},
      "finish_reason": "stop"
    }
  ],
  "usage": {"prompt_tokens": 20, "completion_tokens": 40, "total_tokens": 60}
}

2. SOAP/WSDL Hypothetical

SOAP is XML-based, so we'd first define a WSDL contract:

xml
Copy code
<definitions name="OpenAIChatService"
             targetNamespace="http://api.openai.com/soap"
             xmlns:tns="http://api.openai.com/soap"
             xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/soap/"
             xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
             xmlns="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/">

  <!-- Message types -->
  <message name="CreateChatCompletionRequest">
    <part name="model" type="xsd:string"/>
    <part name="temperature" type="xsd:float"/>
    <part name="stream" type="xsd:boolean"/>
    <part name="messages" type="tns:ArrayOfMessage"/>
  </message>

  <message name="CreateChatCompletionResponse">
    <part name="id" type="xsd:string"/>
    <part name="output" type="tns:ChatOutput"/>
    <part name="usage" type="tns:Usage"/>
  </message>

  <!-- Types -->
  <types>
    <xsd:schema targetNamespace="http://api.openai.com/soap">
      <xsd:complexType name="Message">
        <xsd:sequence>
          <xsd:element name="role" type="xsd:string"/>
          <xsd:element name="content" type="xsd:string"/>
        </xsd:sequence>
      </xsd:complexType>

      <xsd:complexType name="ArrayOfMessage">
        <xsd:sequence>
          <xsd:element name="message" type="tns:Message" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
        </xsd:sequence>
      </xsd:complexType>

      <xsd:complexType name="ChatOutput">
        <xsd:sequence>
          <xsd:element name="content" type="xsd:string"/>
          <xsd:element name="finish_reason" type="xsd:string"/>
        </xsd:sequence>
      </xsd:complexType>

      <xsd:complexType name="Usage">
        <xsd:sequence>
          <xsd:element name="prompt_tokens" type="xsd:int"/>
          <xsd:element name="completion_tokens" type="xsd:int"/>
          <xsd:element name="total_tokens" type="xsd:int"/>
        </xsd:sequence>
      </xsd:complexType>
    </xsd:schema>
  </types>

  <!-- Port & Binding -->
  <portType name="ChatPortType">
    <operation name="CreateChatCompletion">
      <input message="tns:CreateChatCompletionRequest"/>
      <output message="tns:CreateChatCompletionResponse"/>
    </operation>
  </portType>

  <binding name="ChatBinding" type="tns:ChatPortType">
    <soap:binding style="document"
                  transport="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/http"/>
    <operation name="CreateChatCompletion">
      <soap:operation soapAction="createChatCompletion"/>
      <input><soap:body use="literal"/></input>
      <output><soap:body use="literal"/></output>
    </operation>
  </binding>

  <service name="OpenAIChatService">
    <port name="ChatPort" binding="tns:ChatBinding">
      <soap:address location="https://api.openai.com/soap"/>
    </port>
  </service>
</definitions>

3. Example SOAP Request

Copy code
<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/"
                  xmlns:api="http://api.openai.com/soap">
   <soapenv:Header>
      <api:AuthToken>Bearer-abc123</api:AuthToken>
   </soapenv:Header>
   <soapenv:Body>
      <api:CreateChatCompletionRequest>
         <api:model>gpt-4.1</api:model>
         <api:temperature>0.7</api:temperature>
         <api:stream>false</api:stream>
         <api:messages>
            <api:message>
               <api:role>system</api:role>
               <api:content>You are a helpful assistant.</api:content>
            </api:message>
            <api:message>
               <api:role>user</api:role>
               <api:content>Write me a poem about SOAP vs JSON.</api:content>
            </api:message>
         </api:messages>
      </api:CreateChatCompletionRequest>
   </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>

4. Example SOAP Response
xml
Copy code

                  xmlns:api="http://api.openai.com/soap">
   <soapenv:Body>
      <api:CreateChatCompletionResponse>
         <api:id>chatcmpl-123</api:id>
         <api:output>
            <api:content>Here's a poem...</api:content>
            <api:finish_reason>stop</api:finish_reason>
         </api:output>
         <api:usage>
            <api:prompt_tokens>20</api:prompt_tokens>
            <api:completion_tokens>40</api:completion_tokens>

   </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>

üîë Key Differences
Aspect	REST/JSON (OpenAI today)	SOAP/WSDL (hypothetical)
Contract	Informal, docs + JSON schema examples	Formal WSDL (machine-readable, type-safe)
Payload	Lightweight JSON	Verbose XML envelopes
Error Handling	Custom {error: {...}} format	Standardized <Fault> element
Security	API keys in headers	Could use WS-Security (sign/encrypt per-field)
Transport	HTTP only	Any (HTTP, SMTP, JMS, MQ)
Ease of use	curl friendly, minimal boilerplate	Requires generated clients / SOAP libs

üëâ So: SOAP gives you contracts, type-safety, and enterprise features, but at the cost of verbosity and developer friendliness. REST/JSON is fast and simple, which is why OpenAI/Anthropic/Hugging Face all went that way.

‚Äî so you can compare how structured error handling differs from JSON APIs?
Yes, please. Let's see that comparison.

Great ‚Äî let's show how error handling looks side-by-side.

1. REST/JSON Error (OpenAI-style today)

For example, if you pass an invalid API key to OpenAI:

json
Copy code
{
  "error": {
    "message": "Incorrect API key provided: sk-abc123",
    "type": "invalid_request_error",
    "param": null,
    "code": "invalid_api_key"
  }
}


Structure is ad hoc JSON.

Different providers (Anthropic, Hugging Face) use slightly different shapes.

No formal guarantee across APIs.

The client must read docs or code to know what fields mean.

2. SOAP Fault (hypothetical)

SOAP has a standardized <Fault> block defined in the spec, so all clients know how to parse it:

xml
Copy code
<soap:Envelope xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
   <soap:Body>
      <soap:Fault>
         <faultcode>soap:Client.Authentication</faultcode>
         <faultstring>Invalid API Key</faultstring>
         <detail>
            <api:Error xmlns:api="http://api.openai.com/soap">
               <api:code>invalid_api_key</api:code>
               <api:message>Incorrect API key provided: sk-abc123</api:message>
               <api:param xsi:nil="true"
                          xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"/>
            </api:Error>
         </detail>
      </soap:Fault>
   </soap:Body>
</soap:Envelope>


faultcode: machine-readable classification (here, authentication issue).

faultstring: human-readable error message.

detail: arbitrary structured XML for provider-specific info.

Every SOAP client (Java, .NET, etc.) already knows how to deserialize a <Fault> ‚Äî no need to check docs.

üîë Comparison
Aspect	REST/JSON Error (today)	SOAP Fault (hypothetical)
Format	Custom JSON shape per provider	Standardized <Fault> element
Parsing	Must read docs; inconsistent between APIs	Built-in to SOAP spec, client libraries auto-handle
Extensibility	Providers add custom fields (e.g., code)	Provider can extend <detail> without breaking clients
Interoperability	Easy in JavaScript, Python, curl	Easy in Java/.NET enterprise systems, verbose elsewhere

‚úÖ Takeaway: SOAP's error handling is rigid and interoperable (good for enterprise, tooling, and codegen). REST/JSON is flexible and lightweight, but requires developers to adapt to each provider's custom schema.

Hugging Face's error patterns are less clearly documented in the same structured way (or at least less widely cited), but there are community reports and constraints showing variation and limitations:

Summary & Comparison (JSON API vs SOAP Fault)
Feature	JSON APIs (OpenAI / Anthropic / HF)	SOAP Fault Approach
Error wrapper structure	Each provider has its own JSON shape (e.g. {"error": {...}}, or {"type":"error", "error": {...}})	Uniform <soap:Fault> envelope, always present on fault
Client handling	Clients must inspect fields like error.type, error.code, param etc., and interpret them per provider	Clients always look for <faultcode>, <faultstring>, and optional <detail> ‚Äî consistent
Non-JSON or malformed responses	JSON parse errors can bubble up if the server returns HTML, plain text, or invalid JSON unexpectedly	Unlikely: SOAP servers are expected to always return well-formed XML, even for errors
Extensibility	Providers can add extra fields (e.g. request_id, debugging info) but clients must handle unknown fields gracefully	Extra structured details go in <detail>; clients ignore parts they don't understand
Error classification

vary by provider; no shared standard across providers	Standard faultcode taxonomy (e.g. Client, Server, VersionMismatch, MustUnderstand) plus extensible local codes
Interoperability	Must build adapters per provider, or use SDKs	Clients auto-handle faults across services without provider-specific logic

Because JSON APIs across AI providers are not standardized, your client code often needs custom error-handling logic for each provider. SOAP's uniform fault model would avoid that ‚Äî at the cost of verbosity and inflexibility.

Does SOAP have a standardized streaming format that could represent a streaming response?

That's a sharp question ‚Äî and it gets to one of SOAP's biggest mismatches with modern AI APIs like OpenAI/Anthropic/Hugging Face.

Short answer

SOAP does not have a standardized mechanism for progressive streaming responses like you see with JSON/HTTP chunked transfer (e.g. Server-Sent Events, WebSockets).

SOAP was designed for discrete request‚Äìresponse transactions, not long-lived streams. However, there are some extensions and workarounds.

Longer breakdown
1. What SOAP does support

WS-ReliableMessaging: ensures guaranteed delivery across multiple SOAP messages.

WS-Eventing / WS-Notification: allow a server to send events back to a client, kind of like pub/sub.

MTOM (Message Transmission Optimization Mechanism): for efficiently sending large binary payloads (e.g., attachments) in chunks.

üëâ These let you simulate asynchronous communication, but they aren't the same as

like OpenAI's stream: true.

2. Why streaming is tricky in SOAP

Envelope rigidity: Every SOAP message must be a complete XML <Envelope> with <Header> + <Body>. You can't just keep appending partial XML fragments without breaking well-formedness.

Transport assumptions: SOAP traditionally runs over HTTP request/response. Once the server closes the response, that's it. No incremental flushes are standard.

Tooling expectations: SOAP client libraries usually expect the full XML to parse into objects at once, not incrementally.

3. Workarounds that have been used

Chunked transfer with multiple SOAP messages: The server sends multiple <Envelope> messages back over a single HTTP connection (like multipart MIME). The client processes each as a discrete
WS-Eventing subscription: Instead of

one call, the client subscribes to a topic, and the service pushes multiple SOAP messages back asynchronously.

Polling: A SOAP client keeps asking

which mimics streaming but with higher latency.

4. Why AI APIs didn't choose SOAP for streaming

Modern AI APIs need:

Low-latency, token-by-token streaming.

Incremental flushing over HTTP/2, HTTP/3, or WebSockets.

Simple developer ergonomics (fetch + ReadableStream, curl with --no-buffer, etc.).

SOAP would require reinventing a streaming extension (likely WS-Eventing or multipart SOAP) and specialized client support. JSON over SSE/WebSockets was much easier and already aligned with browser and server tooling.

‚úÖ Conclusion

SOAP has no standardized streaming format comparable to JSON streaming. It was designed for transactional RPC-style calls. If you tried to stream AI completions with SOAP, you'd need a nonstandard hack ‚Äî like splitting the stream into multiple SOAP envelopes, or layering WS-Eventing.

That's one of the main reasons why SOAP is poorly suited to modern LLM APIs, which rely heavily on streaming responses.

I'm thinking about a hybrid system where one posts requests via soap and then receive an id. That id can be used on different endpoints to receive the endpoint in many formats including soap, json, streaming sse, websocket, etc. One should be able to access full  and pending conversations, messages, ranges, etc. does what I'm saying sound reasonable?
Yes ‚Äî what you're describing makes a lot of sense, and in fact it resembles how many

systems already try to reconcile SOAP/strict contracts with modern streaming/web APIs. Let's unpack it.

üîë The Hybrid Architecture You're Suggesting

Submit request via SOAP

Client sends a strict, WSDL-validated SOAP request (CreateChatCompletionRequest).

Server returns a conversation/job ID (e.g. conv-123).

‚úÖ This keeps enterprise clients happy: strong typing, WS-Security, reliable messaging, etc.

Decouple response retrieval from the SOAP call

Instead of SOAP trying to stream tokens, the response is stored internally.

The ID acts as a resource handle for that conversation.

Fetch results via multiple modalities

SOAP endpoint: GetChatCompletion(conv-123) returns the entire result in a SOAP envelope.

JSON REST endpoint: GET /v1/completions/conv-123 returns the result in the OpenAI-style JSON format.

Streaming endpoints:

GET /v1/completions/conv-123/stream ‚Üí SSE (token stream).

ws://.../conv-123 ‚Üí WebSocket for incremental delivery.

Resource navigation

GET /v1/conversations/conv-123/messages?range=0-50 ‚Üí partial conversation fetch.

SOAP equivalent: GetConversationMessages(conv-123, start=0, end=50).

This lets clients explore pending messages as they're being generated.

‚úÖ Why this is Reasonable

Best of both worlds: SOAP for strong contracts and enterprise integration, JSON/SSE/WebSockets for modern devs and low-latency UX.

Consistent resource model: Everything is keyed by the conversation/message ID, so you unify storage & retrieval.

Extensible: You can layer in formats (GraphQL, gRPC, etc.) later ‚Äî all backed by the same internal state machine.

Follows precedent: Job-queue style APIs (AWS, Azure, Hugging Face async inference) already do this: submit ‚Üí get job ID ‚Üí poll/stream.

‚ö†Ô∏è Tradeoffs

Extra indirection: SOAP clients don't get immediate responses ‚Äî they must do a second call to fetch results. (But this is normal in enterprise messaging systems.)

Complexity in backend: You need a durable state store (so conv-123 is retrievable across multiple protocols).

Consistency across formats: You'll need to ensure that SOAP, JSON, and streaming views all reflect the same canonical conversation state.

üõ†Ô∏è Possible Workflow Example

Step 1 ‚Äî SOAP Request (submit):

xml
Copy code
<CreateChatCompletionRequest>
   <model>gpt-4.1</model>
   <messages>...</messages>
</CreateChatCompletionRequest>


SOAP Response:

xml
Copy code

   <conversation_id>conv-123</conversation_id>
   <status>pending</status>
</CreateChatCompletionResponse>


Step 2 ‚Äî Streaming (JSON SSE):

bash
Copy code
GET /v1/conversations/conv-123/stream


Server pushes incremental chunks like OpenAI does today.

Step 3 ‚Äî SOAP Retrieval (full result):

xml
Copy code
<GetChatCompletionRequest>
   <conversation_id>conv-123</conversation_id>
</GetChatCompletionRequest>


Response:

xml
Copy code

   <output>Here's the assistant's full reply...</output>
   <usage>...</usage>
</GetChatCompletionResponse>

üöÄ Bottom Line

Yes ‚Äî your idea is very reasonable.
It treats SOAP as a submission protocol (strong contracts, enterprise trust), while separating retrieval/streaming into more flexible modern APIs. That way, legacy clients and modern apps can both consume the same conversation state, just via different interfaces.

Yes ‚Äî that's a clean and pragmatic design! Let me walk through it in detail and highlight why it works well, where you might extend it, and how it compares to what providers like OpenAI/Anthropic do today.

üîë Your Proposed API Design
1. POST /

A single SOAP endpoint that handles all SOAP requests/responses.

Keeps enterprise users happy with one well-defined WSDL contract.

Could handle operations like CreateChatCompletion, GetConversationMessages, etc. all via SOAP <Body> content.

Advantages

One endpoint, predictable contract.

Works with SOAP toolchains (Java/.NET/WSDL codegen).

Keeps SOAP

away from the rest of the system.

2. GET /chat/:chatid

Multi-modal retrieval endpoint.

Query params determine representation:

type=json|xml|plain|srt|markdown|... (content encoding)

format=openai|anthropic|huggingface|soap|... (structural schema)

Streaming

Same endpoint supports SSE (when Accept: text/event-stream) or WebSockets (when upgraded).

Example:

GET /chat/conv-123?type=json&format=openai ‚Üí JSON chunks like OpenAI today.

GET /chat/conv-123?type=xml&format=soap ‚Üí SOAP-wrapped response.

GET /chat/conv-123?type=plain&format=anthropic ‚Üí plain text Claude-style.

Advantages

One resource = many views.

Flexible for clients that want to

Streaming is natural here (because /chat/:id is about the ongoing generation).

3. GET /conversation/:conversationid

Full conversation history (like a transcript).

May include metadata: participants, roles, timestamps, token counts.

Useful for audit, compliance, replay, and multi-turn interactions.

Can be represented in different formats as well.

‚úÖ Why This Works

Unification by ID: SOAP, JSON, SSE, WebSocket, etc. all reference the same canonical conversation state.

Polyglot API: Different clients (enterprise SOAP stacks, modern web apps, researchers) all hit the same backend via their preferred format.

Backward compatibility: Easy to evolve over time ‚Äî add new type/format options without breaking old clients.

Enterprise + modern developer balance: SOAP covers strict contract needs, /chat covers real-time needs.

‚ö†Ô∏è Things to Think About

Negotiation

Instead of query params only, you might also use HTTP Accept headers (Accept: application/json; profile=openai).

This allows better content-negotiation semantics.

Consistency across formats

You'll need a canonical internal representation (maybe your own

) from which you can derive OpenAI/Anthropic/Soap-style outputs.

That prevents drift between formats.

Stateful streaming

Make sure /chat/:id can deliver partial responses and snapshots, so clients can resume after disconnect.

Could use byte ranges or event IDs.

Error handling

SOAP naturally has <Fault>.

JSON clients will expect {error: {...}}.

You'll want to normalize these internally and map them outward to the right format.

üèóÔ∏è Suggested Flow Example

Enterprise client

POST / with SOAP CreateChatCompletionRequest.

Response: conversation ID conv-123.

Modern client (OpenAI-style)

GET /chat/conv-123?type=json&format=openai with Accept: text/event-stream.
